jcr:content.jcr:title: Keynote Speaker
jcr:content.seoTitle: Keynote Speaker | Girl Scouts of San Jacinto

text.text: Every year, we gather to honor outstanding individuals for doing great things for our girls and for our community. And we strive to present keynote speakers who will inspire, motivate and excite our guests. From a young woman who went from homeless to Harvard, to a leg amputee who went on to win Olympic or Paralympic medals in ski racing, to a girl gang member turned entrepreneur- the stories presented at Success to Significance luncheons have impacted hundreds of guests in the best way possible.

text_1.text:
Jessica Shortall
2015 Success to Significance Keynote Speaker

Jessica Shortall’s career has been dedicated to doing good, sustainably and intelligently. She is a firm believer that idealism and realism can and should be best friends. Jessica started her adult life as a Peace Corps volunteer in Uzbekistan and hasn't stopped searching for ways to change the world since, focusing on both the nonprofit and for-profit landscape.

In the early 2000s, Jessica co-founded and franchised a nonprofit, The Campus Kitchens Project, that is now active in more than 35 US cities. She has provided management and strategy consultancy services to dozens of social enterprises – organizations using business to do good. She was the first hire to build and grow the One for One giving mission at TOMS Shoes, where she built the company’s shoe-giving strategy, and helped launch its eyewear line (with giving to sustainable eye clinics).

Jessica received an MBA with honors from the University of Oxford in the UK. Jessica speaks to large and small groups on topics including the opportunities that social entrepreneurship offers to businesses and society, living an inspired life and the potential of women and girls to change the world.

She lives in Dallas, TX with her husband Clay and their children, Otis and Etta. Before having children, she used to enjoy yoga, cooking, travel and a lot of other activities. Currently she's just hanging on for dear life.
